pullRequest.body:
Generalize map liminf and map limsup lemmas. Instead of assuming boundedness in both directions, it suffices to assume boundedness in one direction and coboundedness in the other direction.

---

This generalization resulted from [a review comment](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13938#discussion_r1649744441) of @sgouezel asking for the strenghtening of a specific ENNReal lemma about liminfs.

https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks, and is labeled with `awaiting-review`.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

will be invisible to reviewers.

### PR summary [02931f23e7](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/14591/commits/02931f23e790ed5e72ea409c5ca32f72684f9f2c)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Antitone.frequently_ge_map_of_frequently_le`
`+ Antitone.frequently_le_map_of_frequently_ge`
`+ Antitone.isCoboundedUnder_ge_of_isCobounded`
`+ Antitone.isCoboundedUnder_le_of_isCobounded`
`+ IsCobounded.frequently_ge`
`+ IsCobounded.frequently_le`
`+ IsCobounded.of_frequently_ge`
`+ IsCobounded.of_frequently_le`
`+ Monotone.frequently_ge_map_of_frequently_ge`
`+ Monotone.frequently_le_map_of_frequently_le`
`+ Monotone.isCoboundedUnder_ge_of_isCobounded`
`+ Monotone.isCoboundedUnder_le_of_isCobounded`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10047417389/job/27769080442)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10047417389/job/27769081161)
Thanks! This is a nice generalization.
I think "frequent boundedness" might make sense, but adverbs can't really modify nouns like this. Perhaps a complete rewrite of the sentence would be an alternative. Applies here and throughout.
Isn't the best result stronger than this? That is, can't you get `\forall\^f l in atTop, ...`? Or am I missing something obvious?

I guess `\forall\^f l in atBot, ...` is possible, but in my opinion it hides the usually desired existential (a value of a frequent lower bound) under a less useful quantifier. I believe in almost all use cases one would then have to use `Eventually.exists` + `Exists.choose`, whereas in the current phrasing `Exists.choose` suffices.

I'm tempted to keep the current form, as that is what is needed for the liminf and limsup lemmas. But if you think that the generalization of the existential is worthwhile, I could add a separate lemma with the stronger conclusion. [UPDATE: I am now at least temporarily adding `IsCobounded.eventually_atBot_frequently_ge` for the stronger statement, but I am not sure of its usefulness, so I would be happy to remove it.]

Note: you *reversed* the `atTop` and `atBot` from what I intended. But it's possible what I wanted just isn't true. In that case, you can remove the new lemmas you added. (If it is true, it doesn't follow  immediately from the existential statement)

Oh, I thought `atTop` was a misprint and should have been `atBot`, that is why I reversed (and remarked that at the start of my answer). The `atTop` spelling is just false: it would say that a cobounded sequence has arbitrarily large frequent lower bounds, but the constant sequence of real zeroes is a counterexample to such a wish.

The combination of lemmas `IsCobounded.frequently_ge` + `IsCobounded.of_frequently_ge` says that a (nontrivial) filter is cobounded (in the `` direction) if and only if it has _some_ frequent lower bound. (In particular this makes it obvious that the constant sequence is cobounded and gives the counterexample to arbitrarily large frequent lower bounds.) Maybe an "iff" version would be worth including? I think I ended up wanting that in the follow-up PR.

So I remove the superficially stronger phrasing now. I indeed cannot imagine any use cases for it.
Thanks for the explanation. Obviously I was not thinking clearly.

I now at least temporarily added `IsCobounded.eventually_atTop_frequently_le`, although I am not sure of its usefulness, so I would be happy to remove it. I do think the original spelling is useful (used in this PR), so I think we should keep it.
We're now putting stuff like this in the `IsCobounded` namespace. It allows for dot notation (where there is no text preceding the dot and the expected type is known).

Thanks! This made me realize that I had made a mistake in the namespaces, because they need to be further under the `Filter` namespace (so `Filter.IsCobounded` etc.). I did not right away get the dot notation working with no text preceding the dot, however, but that is probably my ignorance of the syntax, and from my point of view the naming in `Filter.IsCobounded` namespace is good in any case. I changed the naming as suggested.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Topology/Algebra/Order/LiminfLimsup): generalize map liminf and map limsup lemmas
